case.name: Unilever Australia Ltd v Goodman Fielder Consumer Foods Pty Ltd [2009] FCA 1305 (13 November 2009)

citphrases.citphrase: where representation made in television commercial, sales catalogue and in-store promotions for "20%-60% off storewide"
express exclusion of certain goods in smaller print
whether statement misleadingly suggested that every item in store was for sale at least 20% less than the regular price

whether asterisks in banner headings and footnotes sufficiently drew viewers' and readers' attention to exclusions and limitations of advertised sale trade practices

advertisements asserting best seller status with a view to persuading readers to stock respondent's lavazza coffee in preference to applicant's vittoria coffee

the reasons for judgement delivered on 23 december 1999 should be numbered "4" in the series of judgments delivered in this proceeding. therefore, amend sheet by inserting (no 4) immediately after ltd in the medium neutral citation and amend page 1 of the reasons for judgment by adding (no 4)
falsely representing goods are of a particular standard
mislabelled as "styled to reduce fire danger
whether wholesaler supplying goods mislabelled by manufacturer falsely represents
whether publication of statements including statements of opinions made in ordinary course of publication of news (not being advertising material) can constitute misleading or deceptive conduct
publication of material constituting conduct for purposes of sub-s. 52(1) of the trade practices act 1974
publication of incorrect information constituting misleading or deceptive conduct only if conduct contains or conveys a misrepresentation
some articles of news more readily to be taken as statements by newspaper than others
disadvantages of stated case procedure. trade practices act 1974 , ss. 4(2) , 80 , 52 (1), 53 (e), 82 , 84 85 (3), 87 federal court of australia act 1976 , sub-s. 25(6) trade practices
publication of statements including statements of opinion in ordinary course of publication of newspaper

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 4(2). held: (1) publication of statements, including statements of opinion, made in the ordinary course of the publication of a newspaper can constitute misleading and deceptive conduct within the trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 52. there is no definable boundary between conduct which is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive and material which is defamatory; defamatory material does not fall outside the operation of s. 52(1) merely by reason of its being defamatory.
trade practices act 1974 ss. 53(e) , 79 , 85 trade practices
absence of proof of mens rea. trade practices
second offence further manifestation of same fault

trade practices act 1974 (cth), ss. 53 (e), 79 , 85 . the appellant was a manufacturer and supplier of bread in darwin. until december 1979 it sold most of its bread in loaves of 750 grams and 500 grams. having decided to alter its weights of loaves to 680 grams and 450 grams respectively it advertised the alterations in newspapers with the words "prices will be adjusted accordingly". it furthermore arranged for signs to be printed for display in retail outlets stating a change in weight with the notation "prices have been reduced according to the gazetted controlled prices". no reduction or adjustment in price in fact occurred. the appellant was charged with four offences of contravening s. 53 (e) of the trade practices act 1974 . in each case the appellant was fined $4,000 pursuant to s. 79 of the act. two charges concerned newspaper advertisements and two related to the display of signs in retail premises.
whether conduct for purpose of causing substantial loss or damage
whether must be sole or primary purpose
whether conduct likely to cause substantial loss
whether must be sole or primary purpose
whether conduct likely to cause substantial loss

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 45d (1). the appellant, tillmanns butcheries pty. ltd. ("tillmanns"), was a wholesale and retail butcher carrying on business in canberra and queanbeyan. the first-named respondent, the australasian meat industry employees' union ("the union") was an organization of employees including employees of wholesale and retail butchers and employees in abattoirs. the third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents were the president, secretary and two organizers of the union respectively. in december 1977 two of the respondents entered tillmannss' shop in queanbeyan and asked to see the employees. the request was refused by tillmanns' managing director because it was neither smoko nor lunchtime. the union retaliated by imposing a black ban upon tillmanns' shops. at that time canberra abattoir pty. ltd. ("canberra abattoir"), a company which conducted an abattoir in the australian capital territory, held for tillmanns thirty-two cattle awaiting slaughter and the carcasses of twenty head of cattle and seventeen pigs. as a result of the black ban by the union the live cattle were not slaughtered for some weeks and the carcasses were released to tillmanns only about a week later to avoid deterioration. the appellant instituted an action in the federal court of australia seeking an injunction and damages under ss. 80 and 82 in relation to s. 45d of the trade practices act 1974 ("the act ") alleging that the respondents acted in concert to prevent supplies of meat to tillmanns in breach of s. 45d of the act . the trial judge declined to find that the respondents' conduct had the relevant effect and refused to award damages or to grant an injunction. he stated in his judgment, inter alia, that the plaintiff (appellant) was not entitled to argue that the conduct complained of would be likely to cause substantial loss where the means of proving whether in fact it did cause substantial loss were in its power. the appellant appealed to the full court of the federal court of australia against this judgment claiming that an injunction should have been ordered. held: per curiam

the appeal against the first, third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents should be upheld, the cross appeal of those respondents should be dismissed and the appellant should be granted injunctive relief against the above-named respondents because: (1) the appellant was entitled to seek relief on the ground that the relevant conduct of the respondents, if continued, would or would be likely to have the effect of causing substantial loss or damage to the appellant's business.
notice by commission to furnish information
application for declaration that requests improper
person to whom requests should be made

trade practices act 1974 , ss. 155 , 163a. the applicant sought a declaration, pursuant to s. 163a of the trade practices act 1974 , that certain questions put to it by the respondent (the chairman of the trade practices commission) under s. 155 of the act were not proper requests to furnish information within the meaning of s. 155.
